item.title: 10 quick tips for making your software outlive your job
item.description: A new preprint, 10 quick tips for making your software outlive your job, offers essential guidance for researchers and developers concerned with the longevity of their software projects. The paper addresses a pervasive challenge in academic and research environments: how to ensure valuable software tools remain functional and accessible after their original creators move on to new positions or projects. The guide is particularly timely as shifts in funding and organizational priorities are potentially impacting the continuity of valuable software resources.

item.title: Academic Open Source Workshop at CHAOSSCon Europe 2025
item.description:
1. Introduction

CHAOSScon Europe 2025, co-located with FOSDEM, took place in Brussels, Belgium, on January 30, 2025. As part of the conference, CURIOSS sponsored and facilitated a dedicated discussion on academic open source. The workshop brought together researchers, software developers, and open source advocates to discuss the challenges and opportunities of sustaining open source software in academia. With 12 participants in attendance, the discussions were divided into two sessions. The first session focused on understanding different types of research software, their sustainability, and institutional support. The second session expanded on these topics, addressing funding uncertainties, emergency open sourcing, and legal considerations related to intellectual property.

item.title: Academic-Industry Collaboration
item.description:
How OSPOs Support Academic-Industry Partnerships

At a recent panel discussion at the Linux Foundation Open Source Summit Europe 2024, titled “Collaboration with Universities and Enterprises: OSPO - What’s Next?”, TODO Group members and CURIOSS members shared insights on bridging the gap between academia and industry through Open Source Program Offices (OSPOs).

item.title: Academic OSPO Definition
item.description: Over the last 20 years, Open Source Program Offices (OSPOs) have become a relatively common feature in major tech companies and other industries. Many businesses rely upon their OSPOs to manage open source software efforts within their organizations.

item.title: Licensing Resources for Academic OSPOs
item.description: The CURIOSS Community Resources spreadsheet lists all the resources referenced by our members in calls and activities. It provides a handy guide to relevant resources created by both CURIOSS members and other individuals and organizations in the academic open source ecosystem.

item.title: Funding awarded to support the growth of CURIOSS
item.description: The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation has awarded funding to Clare Dillon and Richard Littauer to develop and expand the work of CURIOSS, the community for university and research institution OSPOs, over the next three years. The award comes after an initial grant from the Sloan Foundation to establish the CURIOSS network in 2023.
